revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox football biography | name= Zbigniew Gut | image = | fullname = | height = {{convert|1.80|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} | birth_date = {{Birth date|1949|4|17|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Wymiarki]], [[Poland]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2010|3|27|1949|4|17|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Saint-Jean-de-Maurienne]], France | position = [[Defender (football)|Defender]] | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = | years1 = 1968–1974 | years2 = 1974–1979 | years3 = 1980–1981 | years4 = 1981–1982 | years5 = 1982–1984 | clubs1 = [[Odra Opole]] | clubs2 = [[Lech Poznań]] | clubs3 = [[Paris FC]] | clubs4 = [[Stade Français (football)|Stade Français]] | clubs5 = [[Red Star Saint-Ouen|Red Star]] | caps1 = | caps2 = 80 | goals1 = | goals2 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 1972–1974 | nationalteam1 = [[Poland national football team|Poland]] | nationalcaps1 = 11 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | manageryears1 = | managerclubs1 = }} '''Zbigniew Gut''' ({{IPA-pl|ˈzbiɡɲɛf ˈɡut}}; 17 April 1949 – 27 March 2010) was a [[Poles|Polish]] footballer ([[defender (football)|defender]]) who played for the [[Poland national football team]] in the [[1974 FIFA World Cup]] and the [[1972 Summer Olympics]]. The club football club he was with for the longest part of his career was [[Odra Opole]]. His other clubs were: [[Iskra Wymiarki]], [[Promień Żary]], [[Lech Poznań]],{{ref|1}} and [[Red Star FC]] (1982–1984).
{{MedalTop}} {{MedalSport | Men's [[Football at the Summer Olympics|Football]]}} {{MedalGold | [[1972 Summer Olympics|Munich 1972]] | [[Football at the 1972 Summer Olympics|Team Competition]]}} {{MedalBottom}}
== List of games in Poland national football team{{ref|2}} ==
; 1972 –{{flagicon|DDR}}GDR – {{flagicon|Poland}} N 1:2

–{{flagicon|Soviet Union}}Soviet Union – {{flagicon|Poland}} Poland N 1:2
–{{flagicon|Hungary}} Hungary – {{flagicon|Poland}} Poland N 1:2
–{{flagicon|Poland}} Poland – {{flagicon|Czechoslovakia}} Czechoslovakia H 3:0
; 1973 – {{flagicon|Wales}} Wales – {{flagicon|Poland}} Poland A 2:0
–{{flagicon|Netherlands}} Netherlands – {{flagicon|Poland}} Poland A 1:1
–{{flagicon|Ireland}} Ireland – {{flagicon|Poland}} Poland A 1:0
; 1974 –{{flagicon|Belgium}} Belgium – {{flagicon|Poland}} Poland A 1:1
–{{flagicon|Haiti}} Haiti – {{flagicon|Poland}} Poland N 0:7
–{{flagicon|Germany}} Germany – {{flagicon|Poland}} Poland A 1:0
